Award.AwardTitle: Combinatorics of Manifolds and Stacks with Torus Actions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Under this project, the principal investigator (PI) will develop the combinatorics for geometric spaces (manifolds and smooth stacks) with Lie group actions and, in a complimentary program, explore how the combinatorics constrain the geometric objects and their classification. The focus is on Schubert calculus in a generalized setting, and 'stacky' objects with torus actions. The PI will also use geometry and inferential statistics on graphs to try to derive neuronal classification through connectivity. The overarching theme is to bring powerful geometric tools and algebraic invariants to bear on geometrically motivated combinatorial and graph theoretic questions, and to allow the combinatorics to inform the geometric structures. The project also supports the PI's efforts to increase statistical literacy and public education through her work with journalists and the public on basic statistical and scientific reasoning.

This project promotes the mutual beneficial relationship between geometry and combinatorics, or the theory of counting; an excellent example is describing how to count intersections of certain geometric spaces. Geometric spaces with a lot of symmetry can be described using methods developed in combinatorics, and these descriptions can in turn shed light on the geometry. Similarly, geometric spaces motivate the exploration of specific aspects of combinatorics. The project promotes the use of geometric and statistical techniques to study an important question in neuroscience: how our brains are organized from a graph-theoretic point of view. Finally, the project supports the PI as Director of Research at STATS (Statistical Assessment Service, www.stats.org), where she works with journalists on how to present mathematical and statistical ideas to the public in an informative and honest way. These efforts impact how public policy and legislation is formed; they encourages the public to become more educated regarding mathematics and quantitative reasoning concepts, even basic ones such as the difference between correlation and causation; and they show the public that mathematics and academia have an important impact on society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has resulted in the establishment of world-class training program and resource for journalists seeking support in mathematics or statistics, the training of several graduate students in advanced mathematical tools, and the advancement of research in the fields of algebraic combinatorics and neuroscience. 

The most successful broader impact of this project has been the institutional reformation of STATS.org, an organization aimed to help journalists understand and sort through complex statistical and mathematical ideas in stories they are writing. Since restructuring with an educational focus, STATS.org fielded over 100 inquiries by journalists, wrote about 30 articles, and received over 1.4 million hits on its website. As Director of STATS.org, the PI ran many statistics workshops for journalists, journal editors, and educators, and gave public lectures on the topic of statistics in the media, including some to young children. STATS.org has moved to establish institutional longevity through a collaboration with the American Statistical Association, and the formation of a Statistical Advisory Board (SAB). The SAB consists of 11 statisticians who can respond to inquiries and help run workshops.  STATS.org separately provides media training for statisticians who will feed into this advisory board and/or participate more directly with media about statistical work.

The first mathematical aim of this project was to develop counting tools for complex geometric questions about specific mathematical spaces that exhibit many symmetries. These spaces appear in multiple branches of mathematical, including representation theory, algebraic geometry and symplectic geometry. The project characterized toric Deligne-Mumford stacks, fake weighted projective spaces, and toric orbifolds associated with labeled sheared polytopes. All of these spaces exhibit maximal abelian symmetry; abelian symmetry groups indicate the spaces can be rotated independently in many different individual directions, without changing their geometry. The symmetry is maximal when a simple dimension count precludes additional symmetries. In particular, we used algebraic methods to characterize the singularities and calculate their inertia groups, an invariant one can associate to these spaces. In the case of these singular toric spaces, the invariants describe the way in which the singularities can be modeled by cones that have been “folded over” in specific ways.

In separate work, the PI has developed a method for calculating a different invariant–the “equivariant cohomology”–of a mathematical space consisting of nested sequences of vector spaces of increasing dimension. The PI is currently generalizing these ideas to “equivariant K-theory” and to special subvarieties that are no longer smooth. The final project is being carried out with a doctoral student at George Mason University.

A separate endeavor addressed a fundamental question in neuroscience: how can we classify different cell types in the brain? As an analogy, liver cells and heart cells look quite different under the microscope; neurons with different roles also look different, but one of their key differences is how they connect to other neurons. Can the connectivity patterns be used to describe different cell type, independent of morphological differences?

Imagine that the connections in our brains are determined by a matrix of probabilities – two neurons of specified “classes” connect to one another according to a probability; the probability varies for differenct “classes”  of neurons that are connecting. In mathematical terms, if one were given a directed graph consisting of vertices representing neurons, and directed edges representing connections, could one reconstruct the original neural classes, based solely on the graph?

The PI applied ideas from geometry and inferential statistics to large, sparsely connected graphs to make progress toward this goal. We developed a method to carry this out to great accuracy, using some standard techniques from linear algebra and statistics. Simulations with neurons of eight neural types and a graph generated by the 64 probabilities that neurons of any individual type would connect to one of any type resulted in high success rates, provided enough neurons were used in the simulations. With 64,000 neurons connected via this matrix, the original classes could be reconstructed with minimal error. Introducing noise to the process—through incorrect connectivity information or incorrect group assignments—will allow us to assess how resilient the methods are. Similarly, larger numbers of neural classes and/or smaller numbers of neurons per class, will pose additional challenges. Eventually, these results will guide scientific experiments by providing parameters for which sufficient information can be obtained to make accurate inferences about neural classes.

In addition to these efforts, the PI created, coached, and volunteered for at least six different local science and math clubs for over 250 volunteer hours, providing elementary, middle and high school kids the opportunity to explore mathematics and science creatively. She has also chaired the Mathical Book Award for the past three years, which identifies books that share the wonder of mathematics with children of all ages.
